print_settings.Notes:: fanduct.stl was printed with Support type: Touching buildplate

title: Sunhokey Prusa I3 2015 Fan duct & Proximity sensor mount

description.text:
Click here for Version 2: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1614553

As the 2015 version of the Sunhokey didn't come with any fan to cool the prints i designed this mount to attach to the printer without any modifications. Just remove the 3D printed fan mount for the E3D clone from the X-carrige and replace it with this. I used 2 cable ties to attach the E3D fan directly to the heatsink as shown in the pictures.

Attach the blower fan to the motherboard to the FAN output, and be careful with polarity.

Whats needed:
1x Blower Fan 50x15mm
1x Proximity sensor (Model: LJ12A3-4-Z/BX)
2x M3 screws, approximately 20mm
2x Cable ties
Some wire and connectors...

Instructions:

  1. Print all of the files with 100% infill, make sure that the orientation of all the parts is correct.

  2. Glue the "optional_mount.stl" to the "mount.stl" between the two mounting holes. (This step is optional, but i recommend it to keep the mount from sliding down)

  3. Mount the fan with the two M3 screws (no nuts should be needed as they will thread fine into the plastic mount).

  4. Mount the "mount.stl" to the printer as displayed in the images above (use the existing M3 screws thats holding your E3D cooling fan in place).

  5. Use 2 cable ties to secure the 40mm E3D fan directly to the E3D heatsink.

  6. Press fit the fan duct into the hole of the blower fan, if you want to you may secure it with a drop of glue. (Some sanding could be needed for a good fit depending on the quality of your print).

  7. Add a connector to the proximity sensor and connect it to the Z-endstop (unplugging the old micro switch)
    Brown = 5v
    Black = Signal
    Blue = GND
    These colors might differ depending on the sensor you have, so always make sure to check specifications for your sensor.

    On my MKS Z GEN 1.1 motherboard the order is from left to right
    Signal | GND | 5v
    When the board is facing so that the 12V, Bed, Fan and extruder outputs is facing up. Make sure to connect the sensor in the correct order according to your boards specification as it might differ from mine.

  8. Mount the proximity sensor to the holder so that it's approximately 1mm above the bed when the nozzle just touches the bed. (Make sure the LED indicates that the sensor is triggered, else move it closer).

  9. Follow Tom's guide to setup Marlin:
    https://youtu.be/EcGFLwj0pnA?t=277

The offsets for X & Y for this mount is:
X = 0
Y = -48

Note: In Tom's guide he mentions that you need to modify the sensor with 10k & 15k resistors, however, i found this to be unnecessary for my sensor as it runs fine on 5v, and the default micro switch also runs on 5v, so i only had to add connectors to the cable.

Good luck printing with your new upgraded Sunhokey Prusa I3! :-)

Printer:

Sunhokey Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

Printed everything without support except fanduct.stl.

fanduct.stl was printed with Support type: Touching buildplate

Yes it will keep you prints from separating at each layer and it will also keep the x- axis drive wheel from rubbing against the fan. which will over time create issues. If you take the fan out of the bottom of the extrude setup, unplug it. You can easily reroute the wiring and place it in the front. This in turn gives you better cooling for the extrude. It is essentially the same setup as a better higher end print. The original design is flawed from factory. Hopfully this is helpful

Zenit - Missile ship (Destroyer) Russian Orbital Navy

I've been at it again.  When I did that I-beam some time ago, I made a desk shelf that I'm still using in my office.  The idea behind it is that a small shelf can sit on a desk and actually give you more surface area because you have an accessible second level.  Clearly, there are diminishing returns.  If you covered your desk with them, it wouldn't work so well.  One or two, though, can actually help.  You can see from the picture that from the year or so I've been at 3d printing, I've accumulated a lot of objects.  My wife, out of frustration, threw them in a box.  She seems to like the desk shelf though.

Print the parts, 2 of each, and fit them together.  They actually can fit together in more than one way.  I designed front and back supports to maximize the space in the front.  Also, in the prototype (seen in the pictures), I messed up the length of two of the corners.  Logic being what it is, it didn't matter as the size difference could be made up by properly matching the parts.  I resized everything for the upload.  Let me know if there are problems.  My first iteration required a lot of sanding for the connectors.  I've widened them up a bit, but you will still need to sand a little.  Glue felt to the top and bottom for better aesthetics.

Table Clamp Paper Roller

"Table Clamp Paper Roller" is a strange name, but I can't think of anything better to call it. Perhaps the "Roll-o-Tron 5000".

Here are a couple of videos that might help explain how it goes together:

  • Overview Video
  • Assembly Detail
  • CAD Assembly

The Idea

My idea was this: so many of the packages that you get in the mail come with giant reams of paper as padding. The folks who stuff packages are (happily) a bit lazy about jamming that paper in there, so it comes mostly intact. If you spend about 1 minute of your time, you can roll that paper up and get a 10-30 meter roll of middlin'-to-great craft paper. I've been compulsively hoarding this paper for some time, wondering what to do with it.

Then it occurred to me: make one of those paper roller tables! With CAD!

Design Goals

My design goal was to create something that would be mechanically useful entirely with 3d-printed parts, and with no external hardware so that if you have a 3d printer, you can make a useful object. I also wanted to create a modular system. For example, if your paper roll is 100mm in diameter rolled up, you might want to extend the roll holder arm, but for my needs I don't need an arm that big. Or you might want to adjust the clamp mouth opening for your table thickness. Or you might want to re-use the clamping setup but design your own part that might clamp to it, such as an electronics vise or something.

How It Works

The way it works is: you print four full sets of parts, two for each side of your table. One end holds the rolled-up roll, and the other end cranks it across the table. The parts clamp to the table, and the assemblies are held together with dovetail joints. The rotating shafts (for the crank and the paper shaft) are kept from sliding out with 1.75mm filament cotter pins - you just break off a piece of filament and jam it through there to hold the assembly in place.

I find that it helps to tape the paper into the end you'll be cranking to get it started.

MOAR VARIABLES

I designed the model in Onshape parametrically. You can find that model here. Almost every variable that matters, from the print tolerance and material thickness up to the overall dimensions of each piece, are set up as variables so you (I) can adjust the whole thing to work. I've even included a sketch that lets you create your own involute gears of variable pitch + diameter etc. You might need some familiarity with Onshape if you fiddle too hard (screw threads, for example, tend to be fiddly), but you should get familiar with Onshape anyhow because it is awesome.

The models I'm including here on Thingiverse are an iteration that worked for my particular setup - table thickness and paper roll diameter. YMMV if you download those. I've included both my generated STL files, and my Factory files from Simplify3D if you've got that.

Print Settings

I used a PrintrBot Simple Metal. It works quite well.

I printed these in PLA, on a variety of settings. Generally, if you go with 20-30% infill at 0.2mm (medium) resolution, you'll be fine, though I had luck going faster and thicker on the square parts. I had to print the "crank" at full infill to increase its strength, and I printed the shaft horizontally with supports so that it would have more strength perpendicular to the forces exerted on it. As I mentioned above, I've included factory files so you can see my setup if you've got Simplify3D.

Let me know if you make a print of this! I'd love to see it in the wild!

print_settings.Notes:: To make the most interactive model we printed the tiles, strapwork, and mosaic pieces separately and in different colors, so that Girih patterns could be assembled using the three steps outlined below.

title: Girih Tiles for Interactive Islamic Designs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
3D print and assemble your own classic Islamic-style artwork by using Girih tiles to build intricate woven strapwork!

The tiling pattern in the photo is rotationally symmetric. On the left are the basic colorful tile shapes. Towards the middle we have started to add the overlaid strapwork, which is completely determined by the tiles. On the right, we added gray mosaic tiles to obscure the original tiles and reveal the strapwork pattern.

Girih tiles are used in Islamic art and architecture to create intricate woven strapwork patterns. The underlying periodic patterns that create these designs are related to Penrose tilings and predate the formal mathematical discoveries of such tilings by at least 500 years.

Photo by Guy Sie

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

We needed to print hundreds of tiles to bring to SXSW Interactive, so the printing was split up between four printers: an Ultimaker 2+, an Ultimaker 2, an Ultimaker 2Go, and an Ultimaker 2 Extended+.

To make the most interactive model we printed the tiles, strapwork, and mosaic pieces separately and in different colors, so that Girih patterns could be assembled using the three steps outlined below.

You can create your own Girih designs with 3D-printable tiles, strapwork lines, and mosaic pieces, in three steps.

  • Step 1: Make a tesselating pattern with the five basic tile shapes - pentagons, decagons, rhombi, bowties, and irregular hexagons.
  • Step 2: Each tile determines a strapwork pattern that passes through the midpoints of its edges. These strapwork patterns match up across all the tiles to make a woven design.
  • Step 3: Cover up the original tiling by placing mosaic pieces between the strapwork lines to reveal a beautiful Girih design.

The following models are available for each of the five Girih tile shapes:

  • Plain tiles - no strapwork
  • Tiles with plain or fancy strapwork attached (switch filament for 2-color prints)
  • Tiles with etched recesses to hold separately-printed strapwork pieces
  • Snap-in plain or fancy strapwork pieces
  • Mosiac pieces for adding at the last step, to cover up the original tessellation shapes

Download the demo files to print Girih tiles, strapwork, and mosaics with 40mm side lengths. Or use the Customizer if you want to change style, size, or clearances. You can also download the OpenSCAD file if you want to remix the code.

Basic information about Girih tiles
  • Girih Tiles, from Wikipedia
  • Girih, from Wikipedia
  • Girih Tile Math, from the blog "it's a clean machine"
Online Girih pattern construction apps
  • Girih Designer
  • Girih App
Books about Girih tilings and Islamic art
  • Islamic Geometric Patterns, by Eric Broug
  • Islamic Design: A Genius for Geometry, by Daud Sutton
Upper-level articles and resources
  • Ancient Islamic Penrose Tiles, Science News 3/1/2007
  • Medieval Islamic tiling reveals mathematical savvy, by New Scientist 2/22/2007
  • Decagonal and Quasi-Crystalline Tilings in Medieval Islamic Architecture, by Peter J. Lu and Paul J. Steinhardt, Science 2/23/2007
  • 1-hour lecture on Decagonal and Quasicrystalline Tilings in Medieval Islamic Architecture, by Peter J. Lu

description.text:
Just getting into reloading! Seems to be necessary to push beyond 1/2 MOA and is MUCH cheaper to shoot my precision rifle's caliber: .22-250 Remington, if using reloads.

Glad to see some reloading stuff on Thingiverse already, but to my surprise there was no powder funnel! The "universal" one that came with my RCBS Rock Chucker kit has too much slop to get all the powder in the case when used with haste (who doesn't want to reload faster). Looks like it would work great for .30 cal, but not so much for my less common cartridge. Well time to design a better suited one while eating pizza bagels before getting back to researchy stuff.

This funnel is designed to attach to the neck of either a 5.56/.223 or .22-250 Remington case. With it's FDM compatible foot on the rim of the bowl, and minimalistic nozzle with chamfer, this funnel is easy and cheap to print in any material, AND is still smooth to use despite it's tight tolerances. It's the last 3D printed powder funnel you'll ever need. Download and Make to improve reloading efficiency today!

Note:
"Common cartridge" (.223 and .308 dia) version coming soon. But I currently don't reload any .30 cal so don't hold your breath.

Also I have included images of my parameter names at the end in case someone proficient in OpenSCAD wants to port this to OpenSCAD so we can have a Customizer powder funnel.

Changelog:
V1.1: set neckThickness = .8 mm instead of the actual .3-.4 to help with fitting too tightly.

Printer:

FFCreat0r

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

NO RAFTS! Thanks to the FDM foot. Print such that the giant rim on the top is stuck to your print bed. I printed in RCBS green to match my RCBS products! But Dillon blue or Lee/Hornady red is cool too.

10% 2 shells

I recommend a finer resolution like 150 micron for ultimate performance, but I'll probably bump it up to 200 micron (.2mm) since this is just a prototype. Alternatively, print at 300 micron, but in ABS so you can do an acetone bath....

Don't forget to scale by 3-5% for ABS!

Rip it off the bed (after cooling if ABS) and you're done!!!!11

shouldn't require any fitting, but if it does, I'd try heating up a case a little bit and jamming it in there, just not enough to ruin the lip at the base of the bowl. Definitely avoid rotary power tools.

I was cooking pizza bagels after a reloading study break and thought hmm I should make a better funnel before they're done cooking in the oven. Sounds simple and quick enough.

Required neck measurements of 5.56 case and .22-250 case. Here I am an hour later... but cool I (we) have a better funnel, work can wait till tomorrow, it's spring break :P

It is one of life's great ironies that the teensy-weensy surface mount devices that make today's ultra-miniature electronics possible require a lot more storage space than their through-hole predecessors. This is due primarily to two reasons: 1) they're packaged in tape/reel carrier strips  2) their markings are often completely undecipherable, so if you want to remember what the heck they are you need to keep them in their original labeled shipping bags. For common resistors and capacitors on paper tape you can often just mark the values with a Sharpie, but even folded, those paper tapes are a difficult to cram into small parts drawers.  
The "napkin ring" dinguses of this Thing, included in three handy sizes, can help make your overstuffed parts drawers more manageable.

I printed these in ABS at 0.25mm layer height to save time. Cut the zip closure and any other excess parts from your part's polybag, leaving enough of the label intact to tell you what it is. Roll it up and slide an appropriately-sized ring over the bag.

title: SriCam SP009 Mount for da Vinci Printer

description.text: A da Vinci mount for the very inexpensive SriCam SP009 IP camera (available from Amazon and ebay that slides on to the metal flange inside above the door.

I used this screw to hold Part B to Part C, but a #6 sheet metal screw in 1/4" to 3/8" length should work as well. I used an M3 x 25mm machine screw and an M3 nut to hold Part C to Part A.

this is a quick and dirty protector for IBcrazy's 2.4 GHz Biquad found here: http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1328260
fits a 4.79 square inch reflector, you need to print this twice, for a total of 4 pieces.
I am not IBCrazy, if you are in the market for FPV antennas I highly recomend his Blue beam antenna set.
Everything below is quoted from IBCrazy in the above link:
Full wavelength in cm = 29800/f in MHz
2450MHz (2.4GHz) = 4.79”/12.16cm

Section length (this is simply your full wave length divided by 4):
Section length in cm = 7450/f in MHz
2.4GHz = 1.197”/3.041cm

Element spacing (this is your full wavelength/8):
2.4GHz = .6”/1.52cm

The reflector should be square cut with sides of your full wavelength measurement.
The reflector size is not critical, so do not worry about being off by a small margin on its size.

Q: How is this antenna polarized?
A: If the bowtie is across (horizontal), the polarization is vertical. ie mount it with the bowtie horizontal, if it looks like an "8", you are out of polarization.

This is a package of all the improvements I have made to the Printrbot Plus 1404. These can either be laser cut (via the provided .DXF file) or 3d Printed (via the .STLs).

Included in this package:

  • Extended X-Gantry for use with easily-accessible fan and the option to use E3D hotend/fan
  • Custom dual-zone fan system which cools the print and the extruder separately (short and long versions included)
  • Improved design of what I call "X-Ends" which have the Z-nuts attached and move the gantry up and down. For use with 3/8"-12 ACME anti-backlash nuts and leadscrews.

Enjoy, and let me know if I can fix/add anything!

Anti-Backlash Nuts from DumpsterCNC (Make sure to "add flange option" #2, look at my pictures for confirmation. Part# AC38121-LN)

description.text: In a continuing effort to make both an exoskeleton and a biped robot I decided to construct a space frame using 3d printed and carbon fiber rods.

The construction is pretty straight forward. Print in ABS and drill out the tubes until just wider than the carbon fiber rods.
Cut the carbon rods until no longer than 15cm.
Check how to cut carbon fiber safely first!
Stick the base bits to the tube parts using ABS/acetone glue.
Stick carbon rods into tubes with ABS/acetone glue.
Leave to dry. You can also smooth the surface of the printed parts with acetone.

comments.text: I like what you've done here. The amount of weight you have on there is pretty amazing!
comments.author: notloc

comments.text: Hi notloc. Indeed the Stewart platform would be stronger, and the design is effectively a truncated version of it. I only had 1m of rod to play with but didn't want it to be shorter. Also the final design won't be simply cylindrical and I was experimenting with the best design method that I could generalise out.

Okay, so not every door way in a dungeon is a 10 foot arch. Sometimes its just a door.

I chopped up the 1x1 wall tile and made it into a doorway with Tinkercad, and then made a door using DesignSpark. I used the same concept for holding the door in place as the archway door, basically it a paperclip.

Included are
1x1 No Edge Door
1x1 Edge Door
1x1 Corner Door A
1x1 Corner Door B
Wooden Door

You can't really fit a 1x1 corner no edge with a door, its just too much for such a small space.

Would love any feedback you guys have on these, I know they are not perfect and I am always looking for ways to improve.

remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Metal Fan Cover & Hose Clamp

description.text:
This is a very useful design, acts both as a fan grill and cable guide keeping the Print head cables off the print bed and reducing the strain and flex on the cables at the extruder motor.

My remix changes the grill for a honeycomb pattern and if you like, it can be printed in 2 parts in different colours and then press fit together as I have done. (I Also used a few dabs of superglue)

The fan grill can be used with a fan shroud and can be fit over the cables without disconnecting them. (My remix is a little easier to get the cables and sheathing into.

Lastly tighten a cable tie around the cable guide to secure everything.
Model based on a student's design from: http://thingiverse.com/thing:13912

Ran it through RepG & previewed with Blender, will still have to work on the "Swirly" to get it to print well.  Some overhang issues, will try to work them out.
Modeled with Sculptris & converted with AccuTrans 3D.  Files attached.

A case for the Geeetech delta G2s/ Pro 3d printer. I cut the .dxf files with a cnc router and assembled with glue. I machined the short ends of the big sides with a 90degree Vbit and left the small sides square to get a nice angle... other than that, It fits like a puzzle.

NOTE: The way i designed this is mirrored because i took the outside face of each of the sides. So be advised that you need to assembled however your printer is configured.

The Base is 1/4in Plexiglass, The Walls 1/8in, and the Mounts are 3/8in.
I suppose you could build the entire thing with 1/4in material if you modified the slot in the base.

Really nice design work!

description.text:
Created this for a co-worker that grew up listening to this band. The Ventures rock band was formed back in 1958! https://www.theventures.com/

You can either print the pack as one and use the layout i used or you can manually add each part to your slicing software. Make sure that you print 3 square dowels though! Let me know if anyone has any problems with this design.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed with 35% infill with PLA and also with PETG but you can print what you like. Make sure you add supports where needed. Fitment was pretty much perfect on the extruder and guide however i use simplify3d and have horizontal size compensation on .15mm because my printer seems to undersize everything by a hair.
print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

title: Robo 3D R1 modified Extruder E3D V6

description.text: Modified version of the original Robo R1 wades style extruder. Made to fit the E3d V6 .4.2mm hole for PTFE tube as well as 7mmx3mm deep countersink. Robo/E3d logo added. Also added a ziplock mount to hold wiring harness. Included is a stock filament guide part and a prototype of a modded filament guide i made which holds a PTFE tube above the hobb bolt to help with jamming when using ninjaflex. I havent tested this guide yet so print that at your own risk. Files included are both STL and Solidworks2016 part files.

description.text: This is the library of shapes in order to make the Ace Monster Toys book scanner. It's a moving platen build, using common glass and minimal parts. The current picture is of an old prototype, excuse the mess. Full parts list is currently in http://wiki.acemonstertoys.org/Book_Scanner This design has been tested for the trade paperback sized platen. The shapes library includes a textbook sized platen (upper right), that hasn't been tested & will require some adjustments of the build platform.

An old version of the documentation is up at
http://wiki.acemonstertoys.org/Book_Scanner Newer version (but still incomplete) at
http://www.low.ph/bookscanner/

description.text:
Updates 31th march 2016: Uploaded a Compact-Plus version of the back slider and rodclamp the first version collided with the right slider at the furthest back right 2mm position.

Why these sliders: Wanted to do yet a makeover of my Tantillus printer, and have decided to take it closer to the Ultimaker by embracing their sliders and in doing so, make it possible to use Ultimaker Carriages on the Tantillus. I Call my printer an Ultius Printer.

Features

  • Very compact and sturdy build!
  • Constructed for Ultimaker carriages.
  • Open ended GT2 belt usage
  • Using Ultimaker (8*11*30) bushings
  • Easy to change carriage if needed

Belts, Rods and BOM

  • 4x pieces of GT2-6mm belt with a length of 359mm each.
  • Duct tape or similar
  • 2x 6mm 147mm steel rods
  • 4x bushings Ultimaker 2 size (8*11*30mm). Ýou can either use Graphite Copper or Sintered Copper. Find them on Aliexpress
  • 8x 20mm m3 screws.*
  • 8x 25mm m3 screws.**
  • 16x m3 nuts.

*If you use the Compact-Plus option you need 12x 20mm m3 screws instead of just 8.
**If you use the Compact-Plus option you need 4x25mm m3 screws instead of 8.

Recommendations

  • Use Spacers between the GT2 pulleys and the outer bearings to stabilize the XY rods.
  • The "Left Sliders Compact-Plus" version is optimized for the use of E3Dv6 printhead mount for Ultimaker Original (at youmagine) and will give you an additional 5mm on the X-axis
  • I created some Tantillus top corners w. room for spacers which I'll recommend using.
  • Print in ABS to make the pieces heat-resistant if you plan on creating a heat-chamber, as PLA likes to go soft at around 50c
  • You might want to take a look at my Tantillus (Ultius) lead-screw Z-axis - complete for further optimizing the Tantillus.

My Inspiration
Aside from having build 3psc Ultimaker 2 clones, where one was a printed clone, I have looked intensively at the myriad of different Ultimaker and Ultimaker 2 Sliders out there.
The TwisterBlocks have been a special inspiration in this Projects, which is why I mention them here :)

Carriage used

I have used the E3Dv6 printhead mount for Ultimaker Original. You can use any carriage made for Ultimaker printers.

Printer:

JennyPrinter

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2-0,25mm

Infill:

40-100%

Notes:
  • I have printed these with 0,2 to 0,25mm layer height and infill ranging from 25 to 40 - I ended up printing at 100% infill for final parts as it really isn't that much more filament.
  • Perimeters I used: 2 times 0,4
  • Top/bottom: 0,6mm
  • Feel free to make them however you see fit, but above settings should be adequate.
  • I printed the first many versions in PLA with rather high temp to make bonding better.
  • I printed final version in ABS to make them heat-resistant in heatchamber

Cleanup and preparations
  • Remove supports using a small needle-plier and _scrape_ off any leftover brims.
  • Run a 3mm drill through all the holes and make sure the screws run smoothly through. Especially important for the holes for the screws holding the 6mm rods in place!
  • Pre-set all the nuts into the sliders using a longer screw and a needleplier to hold the nuts if needed.
  • Be sure to insert the "Tight Clamp GT2" pieces (small pieces with teeth for the belt) before pulling nuts into the holes on top, or you can break the slider - Use the small notch to align them properly to the Slider.
  • You might want to put a small dap of superglue onto each of the nuts holding the "rodclamps", so as not to risk pushing them out when changing carriage/rods. They might sit very tight depending on your printer though, making it unneeded

Belts

Cut your GT2-6mm belt into 4 pieces of 359mm length.
The belts should end with a teeth (high) on each end.

For each piece of belt:
Note: this is just to keep the belt in place when fixing the Tantillus Tight Clamp GT2 in place.

  1. Cut a small piece of duct tape: around 20mmx6mm or so.
  2. Place one end of the belt halfway onto the tape.
  3. Match the other end of the belt onto the tape. (There will be 2 teeth right after each other. This is fine.)
  4. Place the newly created belt-loop with the piece of tape in a Slider with teeth pointing up/out.
  5. Put the "Tantillus Tight Clamp GT2" on top of the belt with the notch lined up with the notch on the Slider
  6. You are going to need some sort of plier to pressdown on the "Tantillus Tight Clamp GT2" in order to fix the screws through the mount holes
Remove support using a needleplier Remove support using a needleplier Put a 3mm drill through all the holes and make sure the screws run through smoothly Install nuts using a longer screw, screwdriver and needleplier Support the structure when installing the nuts. Use a plier when installing the GT2 piece to hold the belts.<br>Make sure you install the bushing first.</br><br>If it is impossible even with the longer screw-tip you can use the smaller tantillus_tight-clamp-small_gt2.stl I uploaded the 18 march</br> <h4>Assembly Step 1</h4>Start by sliding the right rod through from the right.<br>Add 1x thin spacer, 1x 5mm spacer, 1x GT2-20 pulley - hook over the belt of the BACK slider. Be sure to orient it correctly.</br><br>Now add yet a GT2-20 pulley and hook over the belt of the FRONT slider. Notice the orientation. Finish by adding 1x 5mm spacer and 1x thin spacer.</br><br>Take some time to makesure everything is right!</br> <h4>Assembly Step 2</h4>Slide in the front rod from the lower (on this photo) side<br>Add 1x thinspacer and 1x 5mm spacer. Add a GT2-20 pulley and hook over the belt of the RIGHT slider</br><br>Put the rod through the FRONT slider and put on a GT2-Pulley</br><br>Hook over the belt of the LEFT slider (check orientation) and add 1x 5mm spacer and 1x thin spacer</br><br>Add top Corners as you go tostabalize it. <h4>Assembly Step 3</h4>Slide in the left ord from the rear side of the casing<br>Add 1x thin and 1x 5mm spacer</br><br>Add a GT2-20 pulley and hook over the belt of the BACK slider</br><br>While pushing in the rod further you need to keep a hand on the pulleys so as not to ruin the belt and slider</br><br>Put the rod through the LEFT slider and add a GT2-pulley.</br><br>Hook over the belt of the FRONT slider and add 1x 5mm spacer and 1x thinspacer.</br><br>Take your time when doing this step. Almost done!</br> <h4>Assembly Step 4</h4>Slide in the BACK rod from the right hand side of the case (lower side of this photo).<br>Add 1x thin spacer and 1x 5mm spacer</br><br>Add a GT2-20 pulley and put over the belt of the RIGHT slider</br><br>Keep the pulleys in place whiles sliding the rod further in</br><br>Put the rod through the BACK slider.</br><br>Add the final GT2-20 pulley and loop over the belt of the LEFT slider.</br><br>Add the final 5mm spacer and a thin spacer.</br> Add/remove spacers as necessary if the belts are not perfectly aligned over and under the sliders.

Used Tinkercad

Used Tinkercad.com as always. It's free and online :)

Recommendations

I'll recommend printing the corners I also just put up on thingiverse, which makes room for spacers between the bearings and GT2 pulleys.
This will make for much smoother running while holding the rods in place at the same time. Same as Ultimaker 2 printer.

Spacers
I used 8x Spacers, each 8mm inner diameter, 16mm outer diameter and 5mm thick. I also used 8 normal metal spacers, each 0,8mm thick.
You might need to add or remove spacers as needed in order to make the belts run directly over/under the Sliders.

Squaring the Axes
I recommend you print and use these two tools from Youmagine:
Adjustable Axis Alignment Tool
Ultimaker XY Axis Square

author: veeresh

title: Emaker Huxley X motor brackets with Z end stop

description.text: These are (now) THREE versions of the X motor bracket; Rhys Jones (with linear bearing mounts, called "X-motor-bracket for LM6UU with end stop and shaft clearance"), JM's updated version with stronger bearing mounts ("X motor mount beefier with end stop and shaft clearance"),  and my latest version with a much stronger Z adjustment ("X motor mount AC").  They all have a precision adjustable Z-stop integrated into them.  I have recently uploaded an idler for linear bearing without a fan mount.  Please see the triple bearing X-carriage at thing 14793 also!

The end stop takes a pressed/dropped in M3 nut. An M3 screw with another nut on it (to lock it in place) screws into the pressed in nut. You may wish to drill the screw hole all the way through to the motor mounting screw hole to give yourself more adjustment room; the model didn't cooperate with me!
FYI, JM's plan was to use a spring to clamp the Z nut against the top side of the nut slot (aiding gravity), rather than as an anti-backlash nut. Using the spring allows a little bit of angular misalignment tolerance in the system. The original system could be very tight if the nut was tipped a little bit in the slot.
After installation
JM's nut system works very smoothly! Kudos! The linear bearing system is much easier to install and adjust. The triple bearing carriage doesn't have any visible slop and is running very well. JM's new tensioning scheme works well.
FYI, if you add superglue the belt is REALLY hard to get out, but it won't slip. Don't clamp the second belt end until you have your Z shaft spacing set. Once that is done, move the motor as far as possible toward the idler and tighten a screw. Pull the belt tight, then go looser until the notches line up (there are pictures of the belt tension before and after moving the motor). Press in the belt, leaving it centered in the belt holes in the X ends. Loosen the motor mounting screws and move the motor away from the idler. Run the carriage back and forth to make sure it runs smoothly. Tighten the screw on the idler side first, then the others. Re-check for smooth running!

Latest update: my Z adjuster broke and I designed a beefier version.  I also added tabs to attach my wires to.  The blue picture is the latest version.  You don't need to superglue the belt into the teeth on this version!

description.text:
This is a holder for the SodaStream Glass-Type Bottles.
The bottles can be inserted with or without a cap, empty or filled. They are held in place by a recessed surface that fits the bottle necks shape (specific to the glass bottle types as seen on the pictures).

The holder is designed to be mounted underneath a shelf board or kitchen cupboard using two screws (I used 3.5x35mm). The design ensures a proper distance to the wall. Just hold it against the wall while mounting it. The distance between separate holders has to be adjusted as required (it should be at least 25mm to end up with an appropriate gap between the bottles).

Enjoy!

Update: increased the hole size a little since I had problems with some screws (now screws with a head diameter up to 8mm should fit)

These are textured 3D models of the Flora main board and accessories. If you are planning a design using Flora, you might might want to make a 3D mockup, and these models will help.

These models are polygon efficient and fully textured. The set includes the Flora main board, along with GPS, Accelerometer, Color sensor, Lux sensor, and Neo-pixel. They are provided in one file, with the modules spaced every 50mm along the X-axis. They refer to the same 2048x2048 PNG texture map.

comments.text: Nice models. I have a question for you. I modeled a mounting board for the Flora main board, which has threaded holes aligned with each of the contacts on the outside of the Flora board. Adafruit's website shows the angle between the contacts to be 19.6 degrees (https://learn.adafruit.com/getting-started-with-flora/downloads), but some experimentation with my model leads me to believe it is actually 20 degrees.

description.text:
Here is my phone camera stand.

The stand is made so it enables rotation in two direction. Only non printable parts are 16mm M3 screw with nut and rubber band.

I used PLA.
The Part 1 (the base) was printed at 70mm/s 15% infill 0.2 resolution and 3 perimeters (0.4). I used support but i'm sure it can be done with out it as well. It came out very rigid.
About other parts.
Other parts were printed at 30% infill. Smaller parts were printed at slower speeds to get better results.
Part 3 has two versions one si for bigger phones one is for smaller. For most newer phones print the bigger version.
You need part 4 two times.
I included .ipt fills (inventor files) if somebody wants to fiddle with it.

The

author: Tutur2479

description.text:
This is a camera mount system for the Covert280 Quad.

It consists of a range of various plates (ranging from 15 to 30 degrees) that slip over a
TVL600/700 camera and then slot into the baseplate.

This allows the mounting of the TVL600/700 camera in the Covert280 Quad.
It gives the user the ability to select their desired camera angle and to change it any time simply.

The baseplate is fitted EXTERNALLY to the bottom of the quad. The user will need to
cut out the correct shaped opening in the bottom of their quad frame to accommodate
this mount. A template for the "cut-out" can be obtained from the covert280
manufacturer and may even be outline-marked in future productions.

It uses the lower 4 front frame mounting bolts to secure it, so you will need 3-4mm longer bolts in the front bottom of the quad.

I have also included a "number" template for the top-front of the quad, Currently
displaying my personal No.5 - you can use a 3D design tool such as "tinkercad.com"
to modify this or to use this template for a custom HD camera mount if you wish.

title: 3D Wings

description.text:
Behold! 3D printing wings for those that have successfully printed something! Show off your printing prowess in style with this fashionable addition to any garment (Note: May or may not actually be fashionable and/or stylish).

On a more serious note, I'm helping to run some 3D printing sessions at the university where I work. I wanted to showcase the process with something that would print out quickly but also be a bit of fun and work as a merit badge to those who want one. It also serves as a good example to the class of what Thingiverse is and what you can do with the things you can download with readily available 3D tools.

Doesn't Matter

No

Notes:

Resolution and infill don't really matter for this, although the finer you go the better you will look :)

This was run at the university Makerspace on an Up Box.

I took the two awesome things (3D Printing Merit Badge & Drone Pilot Wings) and just edited them in 123D so that the badge would fit in the centre circle of the wings. The source file is attached for those that want to tinker some more.

description.text:
this is a bracket and backplate to install the Thermaltake "Water 3.0 Performer C" watercooling block on the Microsoft Xbox One Motherboard.

Due to the 60x60mm hole distance the included mounting brackets are not useable and my parts utilize the screws and counter nuts already included by Thermaltake.

the backplate is slim enough to not interfere with the steel chassis while providing enough stability for the counter nuts to even let you hang the cpu/cooling block upside down

I highly recommend the Noctua NF-F12 PWM fan for the radiator. although you still need to modify the PWM connector for the smaller J7C1 connector on the motherboard and adapt it to the Xbox One mirrored/reversed pin layout of the socket.

description.text:
Update :
A new Spring Loaded Spool Lock is now available :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1433989
It may replace the lock and the spring presented bellow

Here are the 4 best friends your spool can ask for :

- The Lock : Mandatory
The lock is there to make sure your spool is... well ... locked in place.

- The Roller Extender : Very Usefull
is meant to extend the original roller that comes with the FABtotum to allow the use of 1Kg spools.

- The Spring : Not mandatory but very usefull
Best pal of the lock, the spring is their to make sure that the lock will stay in place, no matter what (vibrations...). Best part is... if you already have the original lock from FABtotum, it will be compatible with this spring ;)

- The End Stops : Usefull
just to make sure that this spool doesn't slide off the rollers under any circumstances.

- The Spacers : Just in case
If you don't have screws small enought to fix the spring to your totum, these can be handy. 2 sizes : 7mm & 10mm

description.text: The idea for this came from the thought that there are plenty of places in the world where the tools to create machinery are scarce or non-existent, but thread is typically plentiful. A fully plastic sewing machine could be a real help to people, allowing the process of mending cloth to be sped up quite a lot. This machine is by no means finished, and the shaft to hold the needle is really just a place-holder, but if I can find the help or the time, I may eventually perfect this design!

The current version is not quite a sewing machine yet! Print out all the parts, including an extra both of the 2" gear and the pin. The gears will need to be bonded to the shafts, and the guide for the shaft in the chassis may need to be widened for smooth operation.

comments.text:
It is a good project to start, If you want a help to finish the project I am willing to collaborate with you, as I know sewing machines and I want to democratize the act of sewing,
best regard

description.text:
A girlfriend of mine her birthday is comming up, so I thought I would make her something she likes. She gave us nicknames for a event. So i put those on the picture.

I will also upload a nameless model, so you can put a name on it yourself.

I also uploaded a starbookmark without a name plaque:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1404960

Notes:

This size should be printed with a small nozzle, like a 0.25mm nozzle. Or the letters will look bad. I's are also hard to print because of the little dot on them (i). The extra amount of fillament extruded after a retract is too much and will make it look like a blob.

You could also scale it up to +-130% and print it with a 0.40mm nozzle just fine.

I made these awesome Steampunk Goggles... but I didn't have any 52mm Photographic Filters... OpenSCAD (and MakerBlocks tutorials) to the rescue. It took a few iteration to get the size right, but with a 0.1mm nozzle these are "press fit" with no glue required.  
Made in a honecomb shape to fit my current "bee" theme/obsession.

description.text: This is version 2 of a smaller power cord clip/holder I designed (on youmagine) . This is kind of a non-invasive style solution. This one has a longer width and taller height. This gives more stability for holding the cord.. This is partly due to the fact that the power connector to the UM2 isn't all that secure. This version of the clip is to secure the power cord better than just hanging off the UM2. -I suggest when connecting the clip be sure to power off the UM2 first. -Lay the UM2 on its side -Since this is a taller and wider clip, as you clip it onto the UM2 move the stepper cords out of the way. It should sit between the end and the contact switch. -Clip the power cord into the clip. -Then attach the clip under the UM2 (as shown in the photos). -Then you can slide the clip to the position you want it. (the connections should be snug). -Insure that the power connector is straight into the UM2 power port. -Then you can power up the UM2. This helps me, I hope it helps you all. I'm working on another version now. description.text: This is a serious sheet metal brake to fold any sheet material up to 12mm (1/2"). Actualy max angle is 90° because I used offcuts from the shop. Maybe I'll make an upgrade to allow up to 135° folding and round corners as soon as I need it.

Notes:

Hi guys,

I needed a serious sheet metal brake for some machinery purpose. I tryed to use the best offcuts laying on my stockpile so, maybe you won't find same materials available. Anyways, this is rathe a "how to" thing. Adjust the plans to any material/dimensions more suitable for your purpose. Keep in mind, especialy if you plan to brake metal sheets, that you will need heavy duty materials anyways.

I wish you'll enjoy it !

title: ZMR 250 LED Bracket for Diatone LED strip

description.text:
Yet another LED bracket for the ZMR. This one was designed for use with the Diatone LED strip from Banggood.com and other places.
http://www.banggood.com/Diatone-3-4S-LED-Decoration-Board-Strip-Set-For-250-Class-Frame-p-961260.html
Besides being designed for a particular strip, minimal weight was a goal for this part. There are two models, one that is thin, and one that is very thin. On my printer, the very thin one with a couple bottom layers and no infill, yields a part with only two shells and weighs 0.4 grams. Adding infill will add one more shell and make it more durable.

The LED strips were attached to the plate with double sided tape or hot glue, and holes were drilled through the face to solder to the LED strip to a wire.

The Diatone item contains 4 LED strips, one each with Green, White, Red and Blue LEDs.
Based upon daylight visibility, I'd rate them in this order: Green, White, Red and Blue. I mount the green on the back and the red on the front (like DJI does with the phantoms). When I'm close to losing orientation and need the lights for help, I want the most visible one on the end that is most easily controlled. YMMV

On the ZMR, I mount the front one near the bottom plate and the back one at the top plate (held there with tape or glue), so it isn't obstructed by the my battery connector.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 mm nozzle. 0.3 mm layer height

Notes:

If minimum weight is desired, try zero infill with a couple bottom layers.

You will probably need a file or drill bit to get this to fit through the standoffs on the ZMR. I found a drill bit was all I needed. You may also have to loosen the standoffs and allow them to move around in their mounting holes while installing the bracket. If that isn't enough, you can scale them in the X or Y dimension slightly to make the hole spacing closer to your needs.
